response.answer_text: As others have said in their answers, you can copyright your entire manuscript, but you cannot copyright the title of a book. Titles of books cannot be copyrighted, and you will often see multiple books with the same title—especially if the title is a single word or if it’s a common phrase. However, there are creative elements that can be trademarked. People can apply for trademarks for their character names or the name of a universe or even the use of a unique phrase in certain creative uses. The owner of the trademark can then take action against people who use the trademark without fair use or proper licensing. For example, “The Lord of the Rings” is trademarked, and therefore other authors cannot use those five words in that order to sell a variety of goods and services, including books but also keychains, collectible plates, etc. Applying for a trademark in the United States is a high-effort, sometimes-expensive process. If you believe this is the right route for you, start going through the process orientation a the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office’s website: Trademark process. Be aware that this area of the law is a little messy, however. In 2018, author Faleena Hopkins sued several people for using the word “Cocky” in the titles of their romance novels. Hopkins had been granted a trademark to use “cocky” in romance titles. She was successfully able to convince Amazon to pull down some of these titles, even if they weren’t romance novels, and even if the novel had been published before Hopkins was granted the trademark. The result of the court case is that the trademark was struck down, as the court ruled that “cocky” was not a unique term. (Source: The long Cocky-gate nightmare is over) The media reports on this has led to quite a bit of confusion between copyrights and trademarks within book titles in the industry. While unique names like Harry Potter and Jack Reacher can likely be trademarked, very few authors go through the expense to trademark something that can successfully defended as unique in a book title. When a work (such as a manuscript) is copyrighted, there is a legal basis for the author to defend themselves against an author whose work might cause confusion in the marketplace—which doesn’t have to be the title. For example, the name “Jack Reacher” isn’t trademarked, but an author who writes a novel in which a man named Jack Reacher is the action hero—or even if he shares certain physical or mental features with Lee Child’s character—would likely be found in violation of Child’s copyrighted manuscripts. (The author Diane Capri, who writes “The Hunt for Jack Reacher” novels, does so with the express written consent of Lee Child.) The vast majority of authors simply attempt to title books something that can easily be found on search engines and book retailer sites—and not easily confused with other authors’ work.

First of all, the word is Copyright. Secondly, titles are not able to be copyrighted. But here is a simple answer, from Writer’s Digest: Can You Copyright a Title? | WritersDigest.com Third, if you want accurate info, go to U.S. Copyright Office Also, you do not have to register or pay anything to have copyright on anything you write. As soon as something is written, it is automatically copyrighted. But if you ever want to file a claim against someone for infringing your copyright, it does need to have been registered. Legal action is expensive, however, so in most cases, it’s not worth it to pay to register copyright unless your work is being published. Finally, even if you copyrighted “My Life and Story,” it would not prevent someone else from coming up with that exact same title. Copyright is not like a patent. No search is done to see if anyone has ever used that title before, and it does not stop someone else from having the same idea and writing the same few words (that’s why copyrighting a title doesn’t make sense.) A thing can be copyrighted if it is “an original work of authorship.” Obviously, if someone wrote a new book and called it Fahrenheit 451, it would not make much sense. But there are definitely many books that have the same name as other books. Basic info from U.S. Copyright Office for the US: What Does Copyright Protect?

It's currently being tried and going nowhere by quite a number of folks. It seems that you can't copyright names or titles anymore than you can copyright historical creature items (Dwarves, elves and werewolves). The legality of copyright falls under direct or indirect use. If I have a book called Warden's Folly, Set in a fantasy world of my own devisement. If someone copied the title for a biography about a Warden who committed some shear act of stupidity and called it Warden's Folly. That's perfectly legal and alright on all sides regardless of how it's done. But if he had a fantasy book set with similarities to my own book and called it Warden's Folly that would infringe upon my rights as holder of an already established written book. Now things get murky here because though similar if there's enough difference between them I can't do anything other than politely request they change the name or alter certain things. If it's deliberate and intentional I could have a case of infringement and possibly theft of intellectual property if, If they're close enough for a case to be made. Because it should be given a brief overview by outside editors who can tell you if the name had been used or even if its constantly reoccurring name of theme.

Short answer: You can’t. Titles cannot be copyrighted. Only your written work can be copyrighted, and that is why there are books with the same title out in the world. Even if you have the same title as someone else, you both will create vastly different stories.
You cannot. You cannot copyright a title.

As already mentioned, title of a book can’t be copyrighted. Trademark registration is an option, but a trademark is given only if it fulfills all the criteria required of a trademark application. Any title won’t be given a trademark even if you apply and pay the fee. In general, unless it is distinct enough to represent a brand, it won’t be worth it trying to get IP protection for the title of a book.

You don’t. Names, titles, individual words, and short phrases are not eligible for copyright protection. You can trademark elements of a title that you use to signify a series: for example, “Harry Potter” for the Harry Potter books. Trademark rights are more restricted than copyright rights, however.
You can’t. Copyright law does not cover short phrases. Trademark law is what protects words and phrases, and that has to be registered and costs money. Unlike copyright, it is not automatic
